snippet: A handful of games in, most of them unsightly, discussion of the Knicks’ triangle offense is deflecting attention from a roster that is ill-suited for it.
abstract: Harvey Araton On Pro Basketball column holds that ongoing arguments over whether or not New York Knicks should be relying on triangle offense at all misses more relevant question of why it has been pushed so aggressively on this particular roster; says idea that debut season for team president Phil Jackson and coach Derek Fisher should be largely about setting triangle foundation is grandiose and may actually impede team's success.
lead_paragraph: A handful of games in, most of them unsightly, discussion of the Knicks’ triangle offense is deflecting attention from a roster that is ill-suited for it.

headline.main: It’s Elementary: Knicks’ Problem Is Chemistry, Not Geometry
headline.print_headline: It’s Elementary: Knicks’ Problem Is Chemistry, Not Geometry
